abstract: Henry T. Nicholas III faces fraud, conspiracy and drug charges. He is also accused of running a stock options backdating scheme.
snippet: Henry T. Nicholas III faces fraud, conspiracy and drug charges. He is also accused of running a stock options backdating scheme.
lead_paragraph: Henry T. Nicholas III, the flamboyant co-founder and former chief executive of the chip maker Broadcom, was indicted Thursday in California on fraud, conspiracy and drug charges, including allegations that he spiked the drinks of other executives with ecstasy.

headline.main: Former Chief of Broadcom Is Indicted
headline.print_headline: Former Chief of Broadcom Is Indicted

abstract: The deal catapults Verizon’s wireless business ahead of AT&T Wireless, which falls to No. 2, followed by Sprint Nextel and Deutsche Telecom’s T-Mobile.
snippet: The deal catapults Verizon’s wireless business ahead of AT&T Wireless, which falls to No. 2, followed by Sprint Nextel and Deutsche Telecom’s T-Mobile.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Communications agreed on Thursday to buy Alltel for about $28.1 billion, including the assumption of debt, creating the nation’s largest cellular telephone provider.

headline.main: Verizon Agrees to Buy Alltel for $28.1 Billion
headline.print_headline: Verizon Agrees to Buy Alltel for $28.1 Billion

byline.original: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Laura M. Holson

abstract: Henry T. Nicholas III, the flamboyant co-founder and former chief executive of the chip maker Broadcom, was indicted Thursday in California on fraud, conspiracy and drug charges, including allegations that he spiked the drinks of other executives with ecstasy.
lead_paragraph: Henry T. Nicholas III, the flamboyant co-founder and former chief executive of the chip maker Broadcom, was indicted Thursday in California on fraud, conspiracy and drug charges, including allegations that he spiked the drinks of other executives with ecstasy.

headline.main: Drug, Backdating Charges for Ex-Broadcom Chief

abstract: Monday was the last day, so far, for users to listen to Red Hot Chili Peppers, Led Zeppelin and Diddy on CBS’s Last.FM. Warner Music, which publishes those acts and many more, cut off Last.FM because the companies couldn’t reach agreement on the terms for the on-demand listening service.
snippet: Monday was the last day, so far, for users to listen to Red Hot Chili Peppers, Led Zeppelin and Diddy on CBS’s Last.FM. Warner Music, which publishes those acts and many more, cut off Last.FM because the companies couldn’t reach agreement on the t...
lead_paragraph: Let’s just say, God help you, that some mix of spring fever and midlife crisis made you decide that you simply could not make it through your afternoon without listening to Led Zeppelin’s “Stairway to Heaven.” So you click over to Last.FM, because, as an attentive Bits reader, you remember that site, now owned by CBS, is offering to let you listen to any track you want anytime you want to.

headline.main: The Warner Music Ends at Last.FM
